results.title: Australia
results.creator_credit: Stafford Garner, Stewart MacLennan and National Geographic Society
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Families of the world”.
Join 11 year-old Catherine Inall and learn about her life in Sydney and her Christmas summer vacation on a sheep farm in remote northern New South Wales. Catherine participates in a way of life that is both new to her and unique to Australia. Designed for students from the Northern hemisphere, it is interesting to look at Australian life from a foreigner’s perspective. Suitable for Mid-Upper Primary level students. Teacher’s guide included.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Stafford Garner, Stewart MacLennan and National Geographic Society

results.title: Costa Rica
results.creator_credit: Rolando Quiros, Horst Cerns, UNICEF and Japanese TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Families of the world”.
Captures the flavour of life on a Costa Rican coffee plantation during harvest time when the whole family helps. At harvest’s end the family joins the village fiesta, parading by day and revelling by night.

results.title: Turkey
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Families of the world”.
Shows Turkish village life. Girls weave or embroider, and father and mother farm. At day’s end, the family gathers for the evening meal and later to answer the call to prayer. A trip to Instanbul offers a respite from the normal daily routine.

results.title: Family matters
results.creator_credit: Jack Smith and Granada Television International
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Facts for Life”.
Explains the transition from life in the womb to life after birth. Shows care of premature babies and stresses the importance of mother-child contact. Discusses mental milestones of the first 18 months and comments on the mother’s feelings of being on duty for 24 hours a day.

results.title: Kinship and descent. Part 2
results.creator_credit: Harry Ratner, Ira R. Abrams, Holt, Rinehart and Winston and Coast Community College District
results.brief_description:
Episode number 12 of Series “Faces of culture”.
In many societies, kinship helps to structure the behaviour of an individual. Because most societies organise themselves around kinship lines, anthropologists study these lines in great detail when studying a particular group of people. Covers the matrilineal society of Navaho Indians of North America, the “Yanamamo” people of South America (patrilineal) and the Kipseli village on Thera island in Greece. Narrated By David Carradine.

results.title: Culture and personality
results.creator_credit: Harry Ratner, Ira R. Abrams, Holt, Rinehart and Winston and Coast Community College District
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “Faces of culture”.
This program sets out to uncover the links between culture and personality, to know the dancer from the dance. We are shaped and moulded by the core values of the culture we live in, whether subtly, by absorbing all that surrounds us or directly, by teaching, example and indoctrination. The program looks at the early work of Margaret Mead in Samoa and New Guinea, at Ruth Benedict’s study of the Japanese and Eriksen’s studies of German aggression. Other cultures’ core values - kinship in China, rugged individualism in the U.S. are discussed as well as the dangers inherent in reducing human personality to racial stereotypes. Narrated by David Carradine.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Harry Ratner, Ira R. Abrams, Holt, Rinehart and Winston and Coast Community College District
